including at the Vale council.More than half of council workers said in future they want to have a mix of working from home and working in the office.In a recent staff survey only  per cent said they wanted to go fully back to working in the office.But poor communication, particularly from bosses, was raised as a problem with the sht to working from home, as well as issues with IT.MORE STORIESVale Council: Are you sitting comfortably Vale of Glamorgan Council leader reveals covid- financial pressuresVale council agrees . per cent council tax riseVale Council managing director, Rob Thomas said the long term switch could mean getting rid of some office space.In a report to cabinet, on Monday, July , Mr Thomas said: ldquoWith such a signicant number of staff indicating the desire to work more flexibly in the future, policies and processes should be developed to support a flexible approach to working conditions.ldquoFor some areas, changes to more lsquoremotersquo ways of working were not always positive, with some requiring face-to-face interaction to be most effective.ldquoBut the consensus view was that a blend of face-to-face and virtual ways of working were most likely to be effective in the medium to longer term."This could lead to the rationalisation of office accommodation in the future.The cabinet meeting was the first meeting in public since March, as the coronavirus lockdown prevented councillors from meeting in person.The Vale has lagged behind other councils and the Welsh Government in ing to transparent decision-making.Public meetings will be held virtually, via video conferencing technology, and recorded for residents to watch online.Emergency powers granted to the managing director meant he approved key decisions during lockdown, rather than elected councillors.A list of his decisions has been published every fortnight, with sparse details.Vale council staff also felt there has been a lack of information during lockdown with only  per cent saying they had ldquoenough opportunity to engage in two-way communication, in order to obtain information and ask questions.Only  per cent of those surveyed said council bosses were ldquosufficiently visible and accessible during the crisis, and  per cent said senior leaders ldquorole model behaviours asked of staff.The survey received , responses, or  per cent of council workers.The results also revealed the impact of covid- on mental health.Less than half of council workers said they had ldquogood or excellent mental health, with one in  saying their mental health was ldquovery poor or poor. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe documents cover everything from whether parents should be fined for a childrsquos non-attendance to the possibility of local lockdowns.AttendanceIt would be ldquodficult for local authorities or schools to justy fining parents for non-attendance, the guidance says.But all learners shouldto their school or setting in September unless they have a medical or health reason not to.ldquoThis will include learners who are still shielding,the advice at the time is that they should attend school, the guidance says.ldquoIf a learner is unable to attend the physical setting of the school it is vital that the school continues to engage regularly with the learner remotely.CateringCanteens should be ldquofully open.And those eligible for free school meals should also be provided with them.School unormThe Welsh Government is encouraging ato ldquousual unorm policies after many schools relaxed their uninform code over the summer term.ldquoUnorm can play a valuable role in contributing to the ethos of a school and setting an appropriate tone.Breakfast clubsldquoBreakfast Clubs and after school provision Local authorities, working with their schools should consider resuming any breakfast and after school provision, where possible whether this is provision offered by the school or run out of the school by a private provider.Local lockdownEvery school needs to plan for a local lockdown, the guidance says.ldquoGiven our uncertainty over future transmission levels, for the foreseeable future, it is essential that we prepare for a range of possible circumstances.ldquoThe Welsh Government will work closely to monitor health conditions working closely with Public Health Wales and local authorities, in particular in the case of potential localised outbreaks.How will learners be grouped The Welsh Government accepts that ldquolearners and ldquoespecially the youngest learners cannot socially distance from staff or each other.ldquoMaintaining distinct contact groups that do not mix makes it quicker and easier, in the event of a positive case, to identy those who may need to self-isolate and to keep that number as low as possible.In Primary Schools, smaller groups the ldquosize of a full class are recommended.But in secondary schools, the size of contact groups are likely to ldquoneed to be the size of a year group to deliver the full range of subjects.ldquoAll teachers and staff can operate across dferent classes and year groups in order to facilitate the delivery of the school timetableldquoWhere staff need to move between classes and year groups, they should try and keep their distance from learners and other staff as much as they can, ideally two metres from other adults.AssembliesContact groups should be kept apart where possible, meaning that schools should avoid large gatherings such as assemblies or collective worship with more than one story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityDeputy minister for housing and local government, Hannah Blythyn has announced up to pound. million from the Transforming Towns programme will be used to fund adaptations in town centres to support traders and improve public safety in response to coronavirus.A further pound.m of Valleys Taskforce funding will be invested to enhance small town centres in the Valleys region.MORE STORIESGreen infrastructure grant for Barry Court Road roundaboutSocial distancing measures introduced in Barry Holton Road and High Street shopping areasDistancing measures simply not working in Holton Road, BarryPenarth business owners question Vale councils restrictionsMs Blythyn said the pound.m repurposed capital funding from the Transforming Towns programme, will be used to fund adaptations in town centres to facilitate trading and public safety in response to coronavirus. This will include but not limited to outdoor awnings, outdoor tables and chairs, outdoor heating, outdoor screening, bollards, planters, small green infrastructure schemes, electricity supply and lighting to outdoor trading spaces and the temporary use of vacant buildings and the establishment of local markets.The poundm fund will complement other support targeting town centre recovery including a pound. million Local Sustainable Transport fund to provide better active and sustainable travel infrastructure to make it safer and easier for people to get around their local town and funding to support Business Improvement Districtsrsquo running costs for three months.Ms Blythyn said: ldquoWe all know that town centres are facing huge challenges in light of covid-, but I am committed to ensuring Welsh town centres not only survive but thrive."Investing in our town centres is as relevant as ever but as we do not yet now the longer term impact coronavirus will have on our town centres, it is vital any short term actions have a lasting impact and enhance the look and feel of our town centres.ldquoThis is why Irsquom announcing that pound. million will be available during the remainder of - to fund adaptations in town centres, which will facilitate trading and public safety in response to coronavirus.This will include things like outdoor tables and chairs, awnings and planters to ensure that areas are segregated and safe and that business can operate under current social distancing requirements."These actions will provide a sense of wellbeing, safety and confidence to encourage people toto the high street."As we plan to reopen our public spaces and town centres, we have a unique opportunity to re-think and to re-imagine our town centres as we would like them to be ndash greener, cleaner, more connected.Head of external affairs at FSB Wales and member of the ministerial town centre action group, Ben Cottam said: ldquoFSB is very pleased to see that Welsh Government in creating this fund, has recognised the challenges faced by town centre businesses, particularly as they grappled with issues around the current pandemic and we very much welcome the fund."In our recent report lsquoOpen for Businessrsquo we identied not only some of these challenges but also some of the opportunities to overcome them and this fund provides the chance to make some of those opportunities a reality across our communities."Itrsquos important that this fund is supported by businesses joining with community partners and the public sector locally to identy how a collaborative approach can help town centres survive this pandemic and plot a course beyond it, recognising the long-term trends which are shaping our towns."This fund can be a catalyst for some of those conversations and partnerships locally.The announcement comes the day before the second meeting of the ministerial town centre action group.The group, set up by Ms Blythyn aims They recognise the signicance of the statue and what an affront it is to black people. Black lives do matter.ldquoItrsquos therefore not appropriate to have such a person as Picton, who caused so much suffering and death and misery during his time as governor of Trinidad, commemorated and celebrated.ldquoStatues are not just about history. They are about celebrating the lives of the people they depict, and representing a certain set of values. These arenrsquot the values, hersquos not the person, and these arenrsquot the deeds we want to celebrate and recognise in Cardf today.Mr DersquoAth said the decision to remove the Picton statue had ldquospecial signicance for him due to his own family history.Irsquove written to #Cardf Council asking for the removal of the statue of sadistic th Century slave-owner, Sir Thomas Picton, from the Marble Hall in @CityHallCardf. listed.Cadw, the Welsh governmentrsquos historic environment service, will be asked to give advice, with a final decision expected to be announced near December.On Thursday evening, councillors voted title: virginias state capitol removes busts statue honouring confederate leaders
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThat includes a bronze statue of General Robert E. Lee positioned in the same spot where he stood to assume command of the statersquos armed forces in the Civil War nearly  years ago.The Confederacy, consisting of pro-slavery states, eventually lost the war in its attempt to secede from the United States.The artefacts in Richmond, Virginia are the latest Confederate symbols to be removed or retired in the weeks since the death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police sparked a nationwide protest movement.Virginia House Speaker Eileen Filler-Corn, a Democrat, quietly ordered the Lee statue and busts of generals J.E.B. Stuart, Stonewall Jackson, Confederate President Jefferson Davis, and others removed from the historic Old House Chamber.Virginia has a story to tell that extends far beyond glorying the Confederacy, whose primary objective in the Civil War was to preserve an ideology that maintained the enslavement of human beings. It is time for our Capitol to truly reflect our history. pic GlNyVeoTMmdash Eileen Filler-CornJuly , A moving crew worked through the night, carefully removing the monuments and their plaques and loading them into a lorry and taking them to an undisclosed location.The stealth approach avoids the possibility of protests or a lawsuit to keep the monuments in place, but may prompt criticism that the monuments were moved without public discussion.ldquoVirginia has a story to tell that extends far beyond glorying the Confederacy and its participants, Ms Filler-Corn said in a statement.ldquoNow is the time to provide context to our Capitol to truly tell the commonwealthrsquos whole history.Designed by Thomas Jefferson, the Virginia State Capitol is the first state capitol to open after the American Revolution and was used as the Confederacyrsquos Capitol during much of the Civil War." data-title"Racial Injustice Confederate Statues" data--holder"AP" data--notice"AP Press Association Images" data-credit"Steve Helber" data-usage-terms"UK only" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production dddafbacfbYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcNzgy ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production dddafbacfbYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcNzgy ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production dddafbacfbYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcNzgy ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"An image of the late Georgia Congressman and civil rights pioneer John Lewis is projected on to the pedestal of the statue of confederate General Robert E. Lee on Monument Avenue Ms Filler-Cornrsquos move to remove the Confederate generals comes a few weeks after Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam ordered the removal of a dferent Lee monument mdash a -footbronze equestrian sculpture on Richmondrsquos historic Monument Avenue.A lawsuit has delayed that statuersquos removal, but other Confederate monuments on the street mdash once one of the most prominent collection of tributes to the Confederacy in the nation mdash have already come down. And earlier this week, the U.S. House approved a bill to remove statues of Gen. Robert E. Lee and other Confederate leaders from the U.S. Capitol. The billrsquos prospects in the Senate are uncertain.In Virginia, the Old House Chamber was where lawmakers first met when the Capitol opened in  and was used as the Housersquos meeting place for more than  years before the Capitol building was expanded.It is not currently used for official purposes when the legislature meets.The chamberrsquos history is long and ied, then-chief justice of the Supreme Court John Marshall presided over a trial there that saw former Vice President Aaron Burr acquitted of treason but much of the iconography in the room is devoted to Confederates.Virginia delegates voted in the chamber to secede from the Union in April .A few days later, Lee entered the room to take formal command of the statersquos military.ldquoTrusting in almighty God, an approving conscience, and the aid of my fellow citizens, I devote myself to the service of my native state, in whose behalf alone will I ever again draw my sword, Lee said, according to an inscription on the statue.Seven years later, after the South lost the war, it was the same room where a new constitutional convention met that included black delegates for the first time.Like many Confederate monuments, most of those recently removed from Virginiarsquos Capitol were erected decades after the Civil War." data-title"Confederacy" data--holder"AP" data--notice"AP Press Association Images" data-credit"Steve Helber" data-usage-terms"UK only" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production afdbadfffbddeaYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcOTU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production afdbadfffbddeaYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcOTU ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production afdbadfffbddeaYudGVudHNlYXJjaCwxNTkNjcOTU ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Confederate statues are covered in tarps while being stored at a waste water treatment plant in Richmond, Virginia They were commissioned and built during the Jim Crow era, when states imposed new segregation laws, and during the Lost Cause movement, when historians and others tried to depict the Southrsquos rebellion as a fight to defend statesrsquo rights, not slavery.The Lee statue was approved in  with the help of then-governor Harry Byrd, who would later go on to lead the statersquos Massive Resistance to racially integrated schools.Its , US dollar price tag, about , US dollars currently, was paid for by the state, donations and an in-kind donation from the sculptor.Busts of Davis and Alexander Stephens, the vice president of the Confederacy, were donated to Virginia in the s by Mississippi and Georgia.Ms Filler-Corn also announced she has appointed Delegate Delores McQuinn to lead a new advisory group to advise the speaker on ldquopossible future actions of other historical artefacts controlled by the House.The House does not control Capitol Square, the outdoor area around the Capitol, which includes statues of Stonewall Jackson and William ldquoExtra Billy Smith, a former governor and Confederate brigadier general.The authority to remove those statues is a matter of debate and may need the full approval of the legislature.The Confederate monuments are not the only tributes to losing causes in and around the Capitol, a building built with slave labour where almost every portrait hanging on the walls is of a white man.A large statue of Byrd, the arch segregationist, sits on Capitol Square and two portraits hanging prominently in the Capitol.In the House chamber, directly behind where House speakers preside, is a plaque honouring Nathaniel Bacon.He was a wealthy colonist who led a failed rebellion in the s whose aims including the unfettered killing of Indians and the seizing of Northern Irish sheddie Trevor Carswell, , is through to the finals of the  Cuprinol Shed Of The YearHe said: “It was built using salvaged items and most of the objects inside are keepsake memoirs collected over the years. The cabin displays my children’s first pair of welly boots and primary school paintings, family photos, travel souvenirs and antiques from bygone days. “For me, this makes the space quite sentimental and a special place to spend time with friends and family. “As an avid outdoor family we have always appreciated our garden, but have felt particularly fortunate to have this space to enjoy during lockdown. The shed has been used as a place to relax and unwind during these uncertain times. It has provided the perfect backdrop for family barbecues, nights by the fire and a cosy getaway during the long unprecedented days.”The competition sees  competitors battling for the crown across nine categories. A winner from each will be decided by public vote, then an overall winner will be crowned by a  of shed experts.Alongside eternal shed glory, the winner will also receive £,, a plaque and £ of Cuprinol products.Northern Irish sheddie Trevor Carswell, , is through to the finals of the  Cuprinol Shed Of The YearPublic voting is now underway and will close on Sunday th August. title: calls youth council abc area
story: McConville wins legal battle for web accessTributes flood social media after tragic death of  year old manNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCalls for Youth Council in ABC areaHopes are high that Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon will launch a Youth Council after the NI Youth Assembly has been set up.By Carmel RobinsonThursday, rd July , : pm""Hopes are high that Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon will launch a Youth Council after the NI Youth Assembly has been set up.Alliance Cllr Eóin Tennyson said he is delighted to see the NI Youth Assembly up and running, adding those involved must seize the opportunity to address issues important to them.It follows counterparts in England, Scotland and Wales setting up a similar assembly.Eóin added: “Being young should never be a barrier to politics and as a young Councillor myself, I only wish the Youth Assembly could have been in operation earlier – too many voices of the future could have slipped through the cracks and will be now never be heard.“And this has the added impact of our Councillors pushing ahead to help young people in the area and I’m hoping to see a Youth Council launched in my own council area for local engagement.“We must do all we can to encourage young people, our future leaders, to take an active interest in the world around this today. A youth Assembly is a fantastic setting to encourage debate and allow our young people to opportunity to hold their elected representatives to account. They must not be weary of pursuing their own agenda and really making their mark on the issues that matter to them.“Over the coming two year period the Alliance Party is looking forward to engaging further with the Youth Assembly and we hope to see an inclusive body, reflective of our society today.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
